62: Nevertheless , it is not entirely clear how and when the attackers choose to use the RAT or the rootkit or whether both are used in parallel .
63: Taking everything into consideration , G DATA SecurityLabs experts are sure that the group behind Uroburos / Agent . BTZ / ComRAT / Linux tool/ … will remain an active player in the malware and APT field .
64: The newest revelations made and connections drawn let us believe that there is even more to come .
65: Hereby Group - IB and Fox - IT inform that : This report describes the details and type of op- erations carried out by an organized criminal group that focuses on financial industry , such as banks and payment providers , retail industry and news , media and PR companies .
66: The group has its origin in more common financial fraud including theft from con- sumer and corporate bank accounts in Europe and Russia , using standard banking malware , mainly Carberp .
67: After the arrests of Carberp group members in Russia , some of the members were out of work , however , their experience gained from many years of crime has allowed them to enter a new niche .
68: One of the members quickly realized that they can steal $ 2000 a thousand times , and earn $ 2 million , but also they can steal it in one time and immediately get it with much less effort .
69: The anti - fraud measures employed by banks has pushed the criminals to search for new ways to make money with less bar- riers , compromising and modifying or taking data from banks , payment providers , retail and media/ PR companies are some of these methods .
70: From 2013 an organized criminal group intensi- fied its activity focused on banks and electronic pay- ment systems in Russia and in the post - Soviet space .
71: The key is that fraud occurs within the corporate network using internal payment gateways and in- ternal banking systems .
72: Thus money is stolen from the banks and payment systems , and not from their customers .
73: While this is their main and most lucra- tive activity , the gang has also ventured into other areas including the compromise of media groups and other organizations for industrial espionage and likely a trading advantage on the stock market .
74: In cases where the group got access to the government agency networks their aim was espionage related .
75: The organized criminal group backbone are citizens of both Russian and Ukrainian origin , but the group also sources a number of mainstream and specialized services from individuals and groups originating from Russia , Ukraine and Belarus .
76: The average sum of theft in the Russian terri- tory and in the post - Soviet space is $ 2 million per incident .
77: Since 2013 they have successfully gained access to networks of more than 50 Russian banks and 5 payment systems , and 2 of these institutions were deprived of their banking license .
78: To date the total amount of theft is over 1 billion rubles ( about 25 million dollars ) , most of it has been stolen in the second half of 2014 .
79: The average time from the moment of penetration into the financial institutions internal network till successful theft is 42 days .
80: As a result of access to internal bank networks the attackers also managed to gain access to ATM management infrastructure and infect those sys- tems with their own malicious software that further allows theft from the banks ATM systems on the attackers command .
81: Since 2014 the organized criminal group mem- bers began actively taking an interest in US and Eu- ropean based retail organizations .
82: While they were already familiar with POS malware and compromis- ing POS terminals , the widespread media attention around the Target breach and other related breaches were the reason for this move .
83: While the scale of breaches in this industry is still relatively low , with at least 3 successful card breaches and over a dozen retailers compromised this activity is quickly becom- ing a lucrative endeavor for this group .
84: To penetrate into the internal networks this organized criminal group employs targeted emailing ( spear phishing ) and infections sources from other botnets .
85: This is the main reason why the group is keeping in touch with owners of large botnets .
86: Since August 2014 the group began to create their own large botnet using a mass emailing , but not using typical exploit driveby infections .
87: This last move is likely to reduce the need for external contacts .
88: The first successful bank robbery was committed by this group in January 2013 .
89: Both programs were used by the members of the Carberp criminal group under the guidance of a person named Germes .
90: To reduce the risk of losing access to the internal bank network the attackers , in addition to malicious programs , were also used for remote access legitimate pro- grams such as Ammy Admin and Team Viewer .
91: Lat- er the attackers completely abandoned from usage of RDPdoor and Team Viewer .
92: This approach allowed them to find out that the anomalous activity in the bank network was identified , what technique was used to identify this activity and what measures the bank employees took to solve the problem .
93: Email control was successfully installed regardless of used email system , MS Exchange or Lotus .
94: This approach allowed them to take countermeasures that created for bank and payment system employees the feeling that the problem had been solved .
95: The main steps of the attack progression are the following ones : To carry out target attacks in 2014 the hackers have finalized development of their core malware Anunak that is used along with the following tools .
96: According to our laboratory classification the main malware is " Anunak " .
97: This trojan is used for target attacks only , mainly on banks and payment systems .
98: Target usage of this program allows it to remain poorly explored , providing it a good surviv- ability inside corporate networks .
99: The source code of the bank trojan program Carberp was used in some places of this malware .
100: " Anunak " has the following feature set .
101: One of these files is the program " AmmyAd- min " that may be run with the arguments " -service " and " -nogui " that force it to start as a service without user interface .
102: " AmmyAdmin " allows to connect with another computer that has the same software through the server " rl.ammyy.com " using the IP address and the unique identifier .

106: This malicious program is developed by Russian - speaking authors .
107: In the control panel you can notice a field " Ammy ID " , its usage allowed the attackers to connect remotely .

113: Parallel to this technique they also use another infection method , which was one of the principal methods .
114: The main method of distribution is send- ing emails with malicious attachments on behalf of the Central Bank of the Russian Federation , a poten- tial client or an real counterparty ( at first the attack- ers had cracked this counterparty account , then they used emailing with the cracked contact list ) .
115: Another used method is to install a special malware to carry out targeted attacks via another malware that might appear in the local network by accident .
116: To find such malicious programs the criminal group keeps in touch with several owners of large botnets that massively distributes their mal- ware .
117: The attackers buy from these botnet owners the information about IP - addresses of computers where the botnet owners have installed malware and then check whether the IP - address belongs to the financial and government institutions .
118: If the mal- ware is in the subnet of interest , the attackers pay the large botnet owner for installation of their target malware .
119: Such partner relations were established with owners of botnets Zeus , Shiz Ranbyus .
120: All of these trojans are bank Trojans , their usage is ex- plained by the previously established relationships .

122: The attackers were trying to create similar relations with this hacker , but in 2014 he was arrested , having not developed his botnet up to the required level .

171: While the attacks in Russia against banks and payment systems have occurred over the past two years , the attacks against the retail industry is only something which started in the second quarter of 2014 .
172: With at least three confirmed breaches where card track data was obtainedand a total of at least 16 breaches at retail organizations , it is also becoming a serious threat .
173: Apart from retail organizations it is also known that a number of media and PR companies have been breached in 2014 .
174: While it is not entirely cer- tain , the type of breaches suggest that the attackers are looking for inside information , a type of indus- trial espionage , allowing them to gain an advantage on the stock market .
175: As there is nothing specifically missing and the resulting fraud is hard to match with anything , these incidents typically are never linked .
176: From the retail perspective , the first infections in 2014 were sourced from a botnet which employs a widely deployed crypto - currency mining malware based on the Gozi / ISFB ( banking ) malware family .
177: Based on our insights we believe during the first half of 2014 over half a million systems had been compromised by this malware from over the whole world , however Russia and a number of post - Soviet states were clean of infections .
178: To find interesting infections within this large set of compromised systems , the malware extracts relevant information from the systems including Microsoft Windows organization registration information and network/ Windows domain information .
179: This was one of the main methods for the group using Anunak to obtain in- teresting infections in the middle of 2014 , sourcing infections from other botnet operators . More recent- ly other infection methods , including spear phishing using English language and possibly also usage of the teams own Andromeda , but also SQL injection to breach an organization directly from the outside , has been employed by this team .
180: The first known attacks with Anunak targeted a specific brand of POS systems which revolved around the Epicor / NSB brand .
181: To do this Anunak has specific code to target POS devices equipped with this software , which in contrary to the more common memory scanning track data scrapers , logs a wealth of information from the payments done by the cards .
182: The first case this was seen active was in July 2014 , but it might have been earlier as well .
183: More recent breaches have used a new custom developed POS malware , which is a more simple but reliable track data memory scraper .
184: The initial version from the early fall of 2014 used a simple blacklist , scraped every process and dumped track data in plain text .
185: More recent versions scanned only configuration specified processes and used RC4 to encrypt the extracted track data records on disk .
186: While the retail industry is one of its main targets due to its payment processing capabilities , other compromises might occur indirectly , for example to obtain databases with information or other informa- tion that is of value to the organized criminal group .
187: One of the possibilities is obtaining lists of corporate email addresses to have a higher chance of interest- ing infections .
188: At this moment we have no evidence of successful compromise or theft of banks and payment systems outside of Russia , but several infections in the east of Europe ( specifically Ukraine and Latvia ) were active in 2014 .
189: These specific infections were related to infrastructure of organizations based in Russia or with significant interests in Russia , thus more likely related to the breaches at the same organization in Russia .
190: The majority of infections from Europe were from dedicated servers used as exit node for VPN services , the systems infected were likely from Eastern Euro- pean or Russian origin , and possibly test infections from the attackers .
191: We have no evidence of compro- mises against banks in Western Europe or United States , but it should be noted that the attackers methods could be utilized against banks outside of Russia as well .
192: The group uses Metasploit as one of their main hacking tools , either stand alone or as part of a framework .
193: The activity includes port scanning and system reconnaissance , escalating privileges on systems by using for example the recent CVE-2014- 4113 vulnerability , gathering credentials and hop- ping on to other systems and networks .
194: Metasploit is being used to its full potential with scanning , exploiting , privilege escalation and post exploitation persistence being achieved with its standard toolset .
195: On interesting and critical systems typical hack- ing tools might be found to establish tunnels out of the network , either tools that are part of the Metasploit framework such as Meterpreter , but also other tools to achieve persistence on those systems .
196: The connect back methods seen are typically SSL over port 443 , but also DNS based methods were observed .
197: The attackers use BITS to download files , but also make use of Windows built - in PowerShell to download tools and execute commands .
198: Finally on the critical systems freshly crypted and non - detected versions of Anunak are deployed , typically these are used in very limited deployments thus their spread is limited and detection by Anti - Virus is very rare .
199: Various stealth methods including the aforemen- tioned backconnect SSL and DNS tunneling for compromise persistence and data exfiltration are used .
200: The Anunak malware has multiple ways of connecting to backends , which includes a PHP based backend reachable over HTTP and HTTPS , and a Windows server based component using a propri- etary protocol .
201: The use of VNC scanning and password brute forcing , the adding of additional administrator accounts , use of RDP Wrapper to allow concurrent RDP sessions are all methods to gain access and achieve persistent access to compromised systems employed by this group .
202: Additionally various ways of creating incidental and regular screen captures of the desktop of persons of interest within com- promised organizations were methods employed by these attackers .
203: This also includes video captures made by the Anunak malware , allowing attackers to observe the behavior of users of certain applications .

222: From late 2013 onwards , several banks and financial institutions have been attacked by an unknown group of cybercriminals .
223: In all these attacks , a similar modus operandi was used .
224: According to victims and the law enforcement agencies ( LEAs ) involved in the investigation , this could result in cumulative losses of up to 1 billion USD .
226: This report provides a technical analysis of these attacks .
227: The motivation for the attackers , who are making use of techniques commonly seen in Advanced Persistent Threats ( APTs ) , appears to be financial gain as opposed to espionage .
228: An analysis of the campaign has revealed that the initial infections were achieved using spear phishing emails that appeared to be legitimate banking communications , with Microsoft Word 97 – 2003 ( .doc ) and Control Panel Applet ( .CPL ) files attached .
229: We believe that the attackers also redirected to exploit kits website traffic that related to financial activity .
230: The email attachments exploit vulnerabilities in Microsoft Office 2003 , 2007 and 2010 ( CVE-2012 - 0158 and CVE-2013 - 3906 ) and Microsoft Word ( CVE-2014- 1761 ) .
231: Once the vulnerability is successfully exploited , the shellcode decrypts and executes the backdoor known as Carbanak .
232: Once access is achieved , attackers perform a manual reconnaissance of the victim 's networks .
233: Based on the results of this operation , the attackers use different lateral movement tools in order to get access to the critical systems in the victim s infrastructure .
234: Notably , some of the latest versions of the analyzed Carbanak malware appear not to use any Carberp source code .
235: Once the attackers successfully compromise the victim s network , the primary internal destinations are money processing services , Automated Teller Machines ( ATM ) and financial accounts .
236: In some cases , the attackers used the Society for Worldwide Interbank Financial Telecommunication ( SWIFT ) network to transfer money to their accounts .
237: In others , Oracle databases were manipulated to open payment or debit card accounts at the same bank or to transfer money between accounts using the online banking system .
238: The ATM network was also used to dispense cash from certain ATMs at certain times where money mules were ready to collect it .
239: Please note that the attackers abused the aforementioned services by impersonating legitimate local users who had the permissions to perform the actions later reproduced by the cybercriminals .
240: As far as we know , none of the aforementioned services were attacked nor was any specific vulnerability within them exploited .
241: Of the 100 banking entities impacted at the time of writing this report , at least half have suffered financial losses , with most of the victims located in Russia , USA , Germany , China and Ukraine .
242: The magnitude of the losses is significant .
243: For example , one victim lost approximately $ 7.3 million ( USD ) due to ATM fraud ; another suffered a $ 10 million ( USD ) loss due to the exploitation of its online banking platform .
244: Stolen funds were transferred out of the affected countries to bank accounts in the US and China .
245: Additionally some of the C2 servers have log entries indicating connections to systems located in the US .
246: Telemetry indicates that the attackers are expanding operations to other regions , such as Asia , the Middle - East , Africa and Europe .
247: This report discusses the attack vectors , infection mechanisms and toolkits used by the attackers to exploit the network after the initial infection , as well as the operational details and geographical distribution of this campaign .
248: During the spring of 2014 , Kaspersky Lab was involved in a forensic analysis of ATMs dispensing cash to people located near them but with no physical interaction according to security cameras .
249: No malware was detected on these ATMs .
250: However , Carberp - like malware was found on a computer that was connected to them via VPN .
251: Following the investigation of this incident , in the summer of 2014 , Kaspersky Lab identified the same Carberp - like malware in another investigation involving a bank , where criminals were able to gain access to its online banking systems .
252: In this investigation , we started analyzing all the computers in the bank 's infrastructure in order to find the source of the infection .
253: We found spear phishing emails with CPL files attached that , after a successful infection , install the same Carberp - like malware we had previously found in the case involving the ATMs .
254: There is evidence indicating that in most cases the network was compromised for between two to four months , and that many hundreds of computers within a single victim organization may have been infected .
255: This period of time was used by the attackers to get access to the right victims and critical systems , and to learn how to operate their tools and systems to get the cash out .
256: Carbanak contains an espionage component that allows the attackers to take control of video capabilities on the victim systems .
257: Thanks to this , long term observation and reconnaissance could be conducted .
258: This allowed the attackers to understand the protocols and daily operational tempo of their targets .
259: Based on this understanding , exploitation methodologies and mechanisms were developed and tailored to each victim .
260: All observed cases used spear phishing emails with Microsoft Word 97 – 2003 ( .doc ) files attached or CPL files .
261: The doc files exploit both Microsoft Office ( CVE- 2012 - 0158 and CVE-2013 - 3906 ) and Microsoft Word ( CVE- 2014 - 1761 ) .
262: There are indicators that point to a possible Chinese origin for the exploits used in these attachments .
263: Command and Control ( C2 ) servers located in China have been identified in this campaign .
264: In addition , registration information for some of the domains use details of supposedly Chinese citizens .
265: Obviously , all this could just be a red herring .
266: 6 The targets were all employees affiliated to the affected institution .
267: The spear phishing email messages appeared legitimate and in some cases were sent from compromised coworkers accounts .
268: In this way compromised systems were used as a transmission vector .
269: Given that the victims were mostly Russian - speaking financial institutions , the names of the attachments we have identified were generally in Russian .
270: Examples include " Соответствие ФЗ-115 " and " Приглашение " which translate into " Accordance to Federal Law " and " Invitation " respectively .
271: This is enough to induce a typical employee to open the attachment and execute the malware .
272: For a complete list of file names see Appendix 4 .
273: The following is an example of a Carbanak spear phishing email .
275: In this case , the attachment was a CPL file compressed using the Roshal Archive ( .rar ) format .
276: Once the remote code execution vulnerability is successfully exploited , it installs Carbanak on the victim 's system .
277: The complete list of observed spear phishing emails can be found in Appendix 1 – Spear phishing .
278: An additional infection vector that we believe was used by the criminals is a classical drive - by - download attack .
279: We have found traces of the Null and the RedKit exploits kits .
280: The image above translates as Country_name , All visitors , Unique visitors , Banned visitor , Revoked infections , Infected .
281: Carbanak is a backdoor used by the attackers to compromise the victim 's machine once the exploit , either in the spear phishing email or exploit kit , successfully executes its payload .
282: This section provides a functional analysis of Carbanak 's capabilities .
283: The original file created by the exploit payload is then deleted .
284: The naming syntax is " < ServiceName > Sys " where ServiceName is any existing service randomly chosen , with the first character deleted .
285: For example , if the existing service s name is " aspnet " and the visible name is " Asp.net state service " , the service created by the malware would be " aspnetSys " with a visible name of " Sp.net state service " .
286: If found on the target system , Carbanak will try to exploit a known vulnerability in Windows XP , Windows Server 2003 , Windows Vista , Windows Server 2008 , Windows 7 , Windows 8 , and Windows Server 2012 , CVE-2013 - 3660 , for local privilege escalation .
287: We believe this is not relevant and that the attackers adapt their tools to the victim s defenses .
288: A .BAT script for detecting infections is provided in the Appendixes .
289: Most of the actions described below happen within this process .
290: This file includes the names of the processes to be monitored .
291: This monitoring is performed by intercepting the ResumeThread call .
292: Also , after executing this service , it modifies the executable code in memory in order to establish simultaneous work processes for both remote and local users .
293: Modules modified in this process are : termsrv.dll , csrsrv.dll , msgina.dll and winlogon.exe .
294: Carbanak is also aware of the IFOBS banking application and can , on command , substitute the details of payment documents in the IFOBS system .
295: To communicate with its C2 server , Carbanak uses the HTTP protocol with RC2+Base64 encryption , adding additional characters not included in Base64 .
296: It also inserts strings with different extensions ( .gif,.htm , etc . ) at random locations in the HTTP request .
297: Example of a typical Carbanak request .
298: The commands are compared with a hash table ; if there is a match Carbanak performs the associated action .
299: In order to render the malware less suspicious , the latest Carbanak samples are digitally signed .
300: Known samples of Carbanak have been uploaded to VirusTotal from the following locations .
301: Known exploits that download Carbanak have been uploaded to VirusTotal mostly from Russia .
302: According to KSN data , victims are distributed geographically as follows .
303: It is also very interesting to see the distribution of Carbanak submissions to VirusTotal .
304: This way we can identify periods when the malware came to the attention of potential victims and security researchers , and helps to reveal peaks in the group 's activity .
305: Since the beginning of this case , Kaspersky Lab has worked in cooperation with the LEAs investigating it .
306: During the investigation LEAs shared with us statistical data from their research that helped us to complete our picture of the campaign .
307: The following map shows targets ' IP addresses found in three of Carbanak 's Linux servers at the end of October 2014 .
308: Carbanak uses different tools on infected systems , each one with a different purpose .
309: There appears to be a preference for the Ammyy Admin remote administration tool for remote control .
310: Specifically , the attackers have been detected uploading : Ammyy Admin 3.5 ( f8cd52b70a11a1fb3f29c6f89ff971ec ) as svchost.exe It is believed that the attackers used this remote administration tool because it is commonly whitelisted in the victims ' environments as a result of being used regularly by administrators .
311: This indicates that the attackers did not limit themselves to Microsoft Windows environments .
312: Logs for these tools indicate that they were accessed from two different IPs , probably used by the attackers , and located in Ukraine and France .
313: We have also found traces of many different tools used by the attackers inside the victim s network to gain control of additional systems , such as Metasploit , PsExec or Mimikatz .
314: There appear to be four distinct types of C2 servers .
315: Server rotation occurs more or less on a biweekly basis .
316: For a complete list of identified Carbanak servers please check the regularly updated Carbanak IOC document .
317: The current list of IOCs is provided at Appendix 3 in his document .
318: Some of these C2 servers are responsible for dropping Ammyy ( configuration and executable files ) , the KLG plugin configuration ( list of processes to monitor ) and the VNC server ( both 32 and 64 bits to be injected in rundll ) .
319: In one of the observed servers there was also a Metasploit module .
320: Victim systems are catalogued in the servers ' databases .
321: The victims belong to a number of different communities , thus simplifying administration .
322: In all , 85 different victims belonging to seven communities were found .
323: Additionally , the malicious servers contain video files that capture a victim s activity .
324: While the videos are stored using a compressed format which provides poor image quality , the selected format minimizes upload bandwith and is of sufficient quality for the attackers to understand the victims ' activities .
325: The video file naming conventions used the name of the application in the foreground ( e.g. , Outlook , Cmd , etc . ) and only recorded user activity .
326: This helped the attackers to both navigate to files of interest and to discard superfluous files .
327: Using the intelligence gained from video and other monitoring techniques , the attackers developed an operational picture of the victim 's workflow , tooling and practices .
328: This picture helps the attackers to deploy their malicious operations , for example .
329: In general , the attackers demonstrated great versatility , using attack methodologies best suited to a specific victim 's operational methodology .
330: However , they seemed to deliberately limit the amount of money stolen per victim to $ 10 million USD .
331: This limit may be explained as the maximum amount of money that can be transferred via mule services , or the maximum amount of money that is budgeted in banks for fraud risks in order to minimize the chances of LEAs and the bank s anti - fraud teams from doing a full blown analysis .
332: Sensitive bank documents have be found on the servers that were controlling Carbanak .
333: They included classified emails , manuals , crypto keys , passwords and so on .
334: For example , the file in the above figure has KVC ( key verification codes ) keys that are used by ATMs to check the integrity of the PIN numbers of its users .
335: In other cases involving ATMs , the criminals were able to control computers that had access to the internal ATM network .
336: If the bank had enabled remote access to ATMs , the criminals started using this access to remotely withdraw cash .
337: Criminals used no malware to operate the ATM dispenser ; instead they used standard utilities to control and test ATM equipment .
338: Malware targeting the finance industry ( both companies and consumers ) continues to evolve .
339: The Carbanak malware used in the on - going campaign described in this report has been very successful in terms of generating revenue .
340: Of particular interest are the attack methods , similar to those used in sophisticated cyber - espionage APTs .
341: As such , they represent a new and disturbing trend in the cybercrime market of increasing attack sophistication .
342: Despite increased awareness of cybercrime within the financial services sector , it appears that spear phishing attacks and old exploits ( for which patches have been disseminated ) remain effective against larger companies .
343: Attackers always use this minimal effort approach in order to bypass a victim s defenses .
344: Advanced control and fraud detection systems have been used for years by the financial services industry .
345: However , these focus on fraudulent transactions within customer accounts .
346: The Carbanak attackers bypassed these protections , by for example , using the industry - wide funds transfer ( the SWIFT network ) , updating balances of account holders and using disbursement mechanisms ( the ATM network ) .
347: In neither of these cases did the attackers exploit a vulnerability within the service .
348: Instead , they studied the victim s internal procedures and pinpointed who they should impersonate locally in order to process fraudulent transactions through the aforementioned services .
349: It is clear that the attackers were very familiar with financial services software and networks .
350: As part of an automated reconnaissance phase , the Carbanak malware checked victim systems for the presence of specialized and specific banking software .
351: Only after the presence of banking systems was confirmed , were victims further exploited .
352: To date , attacks against approximately 300 IP addresses around the world have been observed on analyzed C2s .
353: It is possible that these attacks were coordinated to maximize returns prior to industry - wide information sharing and the implementation of countermeasures .
354: Existing telemetry indicates that the Carbanak attackers are trying to expand operations to other Baltic and Central Europe countries , the Middle East , Asia and Africa .
355: Carbanak may be responsible for losses as high as $ 1 billion USD .
356: We believe that the Carbanak campaign is a clear indicator of a new era in cybercrime in which criminals use APT techniques directly against the financial industry instead of through its customers .
357: APTs are not only for stealing information anymore .

362: A cyberespionage campaign against a range of targets , mainly in the energy sector , gave attackers the ability to mount sabotage operations against their victims .
363: The attackers , known to Symantec as Dragonfly , managed to compromise a number of strategically important organizations for spying purposes and , if they had used the sabotage capabilities open to them , could have caused damage or disruption to the energy supply in the affected countries .
364: The Dragonfly group , which is also known by other vendors as Energetic Bear , are a capable group who are evolving over time and targeting primarily the energy sector and related industries .
365: They have been in operation since at least 2011 but may have been active even longer than that .
366: Dragonfly initially targeted defense and aviation companies in the US and Canada before shifting its focus to US and European energy firms in early 2013 .
367: More recent targets have included companies related to industrial control systems .
368: Dragonfly has used spam email campaigns and watering hole attacks to infect targeted organizations .
369: The group has used two main malware tools : Trojan . Karagany and Backdoor . Oldrea .
370: The latter appears to be a custom piece of malware , either written by or for the attackers .
371: Symantec observed spear phishing attempts in the form of emails with PDF attachments from February 2013 to June 2013 .
372: The email topics were related to office administration issues such as dealing with an account or problems with a delivery .
373: Identified targets of this campaign were mainly US and UK organizations within the energy sector .
374: In May 2013 , the attackers began to use the Lightsout exploit kit as an attack vector , redirecting targets from various websites .
375: The use of the Lightsout exploit kit has continued to date , albeit intermittently .
376: The exploit kit has been upgraded over time with obfuscation techniques .
377: The updated version of Lightsout became known as the Hello exploit kit .
378: To date , three ICS software producers are known to have been compromised .
379: Compromised websites appear to consistently use some form of content management system .
380: The current targets of the Dragonfly group , based on compromised websites and hijacked software updates , are the energy sector and industrial control systems , particularly those based in Europe .
381: While the majority of victims are located in the US , these appear to mostly be collateral damage .
382: That is , many of these computers were likely infected either through watering hole attacks or update hijacks and are of no interest to the attacker .
383: By examining victims with active infections – where additional malicious activity has been detected – it is possible to gather a more accurate picture of ' true ' victims .
384: The most active infections , as in Figure 2 , are in Spain , followed in order by the US , France , Italy , and Germany .
385: Dragonfly uses two main pieces of malware in its attacks .
386: Dragonfly 's favored malware tool is Backdoor . Oldrea , which is also known as Havex or the Energetic Bear RAT .
387: Oldrea appears to be custom malware , either written by the group itself or created for it .
388: This provides some indication of the capabilities and resources behind the Dragonfly group .
389: The second main tool used by Dragonfly is Trojan . Karagany .
390: Unlike Oldrea , Karagany was available on the underground market .
391: The source code for version 1 of Karagany was leaked in 2010 .
392: Symantec believes that Dragonfly may have taken this source code and modified for its own use .
393: Symantec found that the majority of computers compromised by the attackers were infected with Oldrea .
394: Karagany was only used in around 5 percent of infections .
395: The two pieces of malware are similar in functionality and what prompts the attackers to choose one tool over another remains unknown .
396: The Dragonfly group has used at least three infection tactics against targets in the energy sector .
397: Infected emails had one of two subject lines : " The account " or " Settlement of delivery problem " .
398: All of the emails were from a single Gmail address .
399: Figure 3 displays the number of different recipients per day .
400: The spam campaign began in February 2013 and continued into June 2013 .
401: Symantec identified seven different organizations targeted in this campaign .
402: At least one organization was attacked intermittently for a period of 84 days .
403: In June 2013 , the attackers shifted their focus to watering hole attacks .
404: They compromised a number of energy- related websites and injected an iframe into each of them .
405: This iframe then redirected visitors to another compromised legitimate website hosting the Lightsout exploit kit .
406: The fact that the attackers compromised multiple legitimate websites for each stage of the operation is further evidence that the group has strong technical capabilities .
407: In September 2013 , Dragonfly began using a new version of this exploit kit , known as the Hello exploit kit .
408: The landing page for this kit contains JavaScript which fingerprints the system , identifying installed browser plugins .
409: The victim is then redirected to a URL which in turn determines the best exploit to use based on the information collected .
410: Figure 4 shows the compromised websites categorized into their respective industries .
411: Fifty percent of identified targets were energy industry related and thirty percent were energy control systems , as shown in Figure 4 .
412: A clear shift in the attackers targeting can be seen in March 2014 when energy control systems become the primary target .
413: The most ambitious attack vector used by Dragonfly was the compromise of a number of legitimate software packages .
414: Three different ICS equipment providers were targeted and malware was inserted into the software bundles they had made available for download on their websites .
415: Analysis of the compilation timestamps on the malware used by the attackers indicate that the group mostly worked between Monday and Friday , with activity mainly concentrated in a nine - hour period that corresponded to a 9 am to 6 pm working day in the UTC + 4 time zone .
416: The Dragonfly group is technically adept and able to think strategically .
417: Given the size of some of its targets , the group found a " soft underbelly " by compromising their suppliers , which are invariably smaller , less protected companies .
418: Identification of this group is based on the use of two malware families and an exploit kit .
419: The malware families utilized are Backdoor . Oldrea and Trojan . Karagany .
420: The exploit kit is known as Lightsout and/or Hello .
421: Hello is an updated iteration of Lightsout that the Dragonfly group began to use in September 2013 .
422: Use of Backdoor . Oldrea appears to be limited to the Dragonfly group .
423: In addition , specific instances of Trojan .
424: Karagany have been used by this group .
425: Karagany is a Russian RAT sold on underground forums .
426: Instances of this malware related to the Dragonfly group are identified based on them being delivered through the Lightsout exploit kit and also a particular packer that this group used .
427: Symantec detects the Trojan . Karagany packer used by this group as Trojan . Karagany!gen1 .
428: The Lightsout exploit kit is a simple exploit kit that is consistently used to deliver primarily Backdoor . Oldrea and , in several instances , Trojan . Karagany .
429: A number of sites that use content management systems were exploited and an iframe was used in order to redirect visitors to sites hosting the Lightsout exploit kit .
430: An example of an injected iframe can be seen in figure 7 .
431: The exploit kit uses browser ( e.g.
432: Internet Explorer and Firefox ) and Java exploits in order to deliver either Backdoor . Oldrea or Trojan . Karagany .
433: An example of the structure of the Lightsout exploit kit can be seen Table 1 .
434: Note that file names and exploits used may vary .
435: In September 2013 , the Dragonfly group began using a new version of Lightsout , also known as the Hello exploit kit .
436: The JavaScript included in the landing page redirects the browser to a URL that depends on the fonts installed on the system , browser add - ons , the OS version , and the user agent .
437: At this point , it determines the best exploit to use , based on the information provided , and generates an appropriate URL to redirect the user to the appropriate exploit / payload .
