993: As adclicker malware is more common with criminal adversaries , it has been postulated that if the same adversary behind Dreammon is behind Pirpi , this adversary 's initial motives may have been financially driven .
994: Overview of Russian Threat Actors Although the Chinese calendar predicted that 2014 would be the Year of the Horse , in many respects 2014 has been the Year of the Bear in the cyber realm , with several high - profile Russia - based actors receiving public attention .
995: The reported activity has included actors tracked by CrowdStrike as ENERGETIC BEAR , FANCY BEAR , and VENOMOUS BEAR , as well as other sets such as Sandworm , which uses the Black Energy toolset in targeted attacks , in contrast to its normal use as criminal malware .
996: CrowdStrike also tracks other adversaries attributed to Russia under cryptonyms such as BERSERK BEAR , BOULDER BEAR , and the financial - crime- motivated actor MAGNETIC SPIDER .
997: It also includes implants for other platforms such as Linux that can be used to operate command - and - control infrastructure .
998: External reporting indicates a targeting bias toward entities in the government sector , along with the use of zero - day exploits .
999: These TTPs , along with the maturity of the attacker 's toolset , indicate that this is a highly sophisticated adversary .
1000: FANCY BEAR is CrowdStrike 's name for an adversary also known as Sofacy .
1001: Although the tools used by this actor are not as complex as those employed by VENOMOUS BEAR , they share a common targeting focus on government and military entities , with a particular Know the Adversary emphasis on Russia 's " near abroad " regions such as Eastern Europe .
1002: As well as implants for Windows , Linux , and mobile operating systems , FANCY BEAR employs credential phishing attacks , spoofing legitimate sites to harvest the details of users of interest .
1003: Proactive analysis during 2014 revealed another Russian actor that has not encountered public exposure , yet appears to have been tasked by Russian state interests .
1004: BERSERK BEAR has conducted operations from 2004 through to the present day , primarily aimed at collecting intelligence but has also provided capability in support of offensive operations in parallel to the Russia / Georgia conflict in August 2008 .
1005: ENERGETIC BEAR has been tracked by CrowdStrike since 2012 .
1006: The adversary initially focused on targets in the energy sector , but more recently had branched out to attempt to compromise financial , industrial , and commercial organizations .
1007: This corresponded with a shift from primarily using SWC attack vectors to targeted email attacks .
1008: Analysis of ENERGETIC BEAR 's post - exploitation activity revealed the use of custom tools for credential harvesting , network enumeration , and interaction with industrial automation equipment .
1009: FANCY BEAR In the second half of 2014 , CrowdStrike Intelligence analyzed the targeted attack activity of a particularly interesting Russian actor named FANCY BEAR .
1010: The campaigns conducted by this actor target high - profile military and government entities in a variety of countries , most notably political institutions of former Soviet nations as well as Eastern European countries , NATO institutions , and organizations of western countries .
1011: Technical indicators , such as the resource locales and C2 domain registrant information , exhibit references to a Russian - speaking adversary .
1012: In addition , the targeting is consistent with strategic interests of the Russian Federation .
1013: Know the Adversary Targeting of high - profile entities requires mature and versatile technical means .
1014: FANCY BEAR exhibits a consistent level of technical sophistication with respect to its tools , and the actor is characterized by a thorough preparation of attacks and required infrastructure .
1015: As a consequence , the adversary can combine the necessary implant functionality on a per - target basis , spanning multiple operating systems and mobile platforms .
1016: A remarkable feature only seen with some of the well - engineered and mature targeted attack malware is the following : If required , the implant can switch the carrier protocol for its command - and- control channel ranging from HTTP over email to removable media .
1017: The latter is specifically suited for target environments that do not have direct network connectivity to a C2 node and instead rely on periodic use of USB removable media to bridge air gaps .
1018: In addition , recent incidents involved heavily obfuscated malware including code flow obfuscation , likely another step taken in order to hinder analysis efforts .
1019: All of these underline a clear targeted attack mission .

1021: Looking Forward Predicting what will happen in 2015 is a challenge , as unforeseen events will inevitably occur and new TTPs from adversaries across the motivational spectrum will continue to shape the threat environment .
1022: Before exploring what may be coming in 2015 , a brief look back at the predictions for 2014 is in order .
1023: Last year , CrowdStrike made a number of predictions about the 2014 threat landscape , many of which came to fruition .
1024: Outlook for China - Based Adversaries China is , by now , well known for conducting cyber espionage campaigns focused on accessing intelligence about intellectual property , mergers and acquisitions , and technologies highlighted in its Five - Year plans .
1025: Targeting these technologies and strategic business information allow its domestic companies to rapidly make " leap frog " developments , and to benefit from favorable bargaining positions , thus elevating them to become global leaders .
1026: This behavior is expected to continue in 2015 , as will continued targeting of foreign government entities in an attempt to access information related to the global strategy and plans of these countries .
1027: China is expected to continue to leverage this espionage as a means to conduct intelligence collection to support its aspirations to further push the envelope on its territorial claims .
1028: This is particularly true in the South China Sea ( SCS ) conflicts with Vietnam and the Philippines , and the Senkaku / Diaoyu island dispute with Japan .
1029: China has already undertaken substantial construction of manmade islands in the SCS to begin projecting its power , and as its Navy continues to grow , it will only seek to push further beyond its current boundaries .
1030: China is aggressively moving forward with the design and implementation of its own aircraft carriers , which will no doubt have an impact in this regional issue , allowing the PRC to project force and intimidate its neighbors .
1031: Looking Forward Taiwan will continue to play a very important role in the potential conflicts to come , not only as a testing ground for malware , but as the main focus for expanding Chinese territorial claims .
1032: The PRC views Taiwan as an inalienable part of China that will eventually be reunited for the greater good of both peoples and therefore places it above other territorial conflicts .
1033: Taiwan 's recent shift towards a decidedly less - Beijing - friendly , DPP - led government is of great concern to China and will be a major factor in how China uses technology to facilitate its political maneuverings .
1034: Taiwan has historically been penetrated by PRC intelligence services at all levels , which makes cyber one of the first visible indicators of PRC intentions regarding Taiwan .
1035: China has also made significant headway on projecting its " soft power " abroad via multiple billion - dollar investments , particularly in the sectors of communications and transportation infrastructure .
1036: For years , China has been making inroads in Africa to provide the vast majority of the continent 's telecommunication systems , but only recently have some of the more sinister intentions been brought to light .
1037: In December 2014 , approximately 77 Chinese nationals were found to be running a sophisticated command center out of a house in Nairobi , Kenya , which appeared to be capable of targeting the main communication systems in the capital .
1038: A building with multiple large satellites that appears to be annexed to the Chinese embassy in Paris was also recently reported on and believed to be connected to the 3PLA 's 8th Bureau , Unit 61046 , which is responsible for SIGINT collection on western Europe .
1039: Image of Alleged SIGINT Dishes at Chinese Embassy Annex Looking Forward There has also been a significant amount of investment poured into transportation projects , particularly high - speed rail ( HSR ) lines , in multiple countries .
1040: China has already planned to merge its two top train makers into a HSR juggernaut capable of building massive rail lines around the world .
1041: To this end , China has submitted bids for massive rail projects in Nigeria , and nearly won ( this was subsequently canceled ) another project in Mexico .
1042: China has also suggested massive lines between Beijing and Moscow and constructing a line between Delhi and Chennai in India .
1043: Beijing also remains interested in proposals for HSRs in Britain and California , and has already made headway on construction of a Hungary- Serbian HSR that will connect Belgrade to Budapest .
1044: In total , the projects proposed by China would give it control of more than 40,000 km , giving it significant control over the world 's transportation routes .
1045: It seems fairly likely that , given China 's previous use of espionage against foreign companies ( which it has used to gain advantages in competitive bidding and mergers & acquisitions ) , there is a substantial motivation for China to follow suit in the coming year as it looks to secure its position as the global leader in HSR construction .
1046: Joint Plan of Action Could Possibly Drive Iranian Cyber Attacks The Iranian Joint Plan of Action ( JPOA ) , its delay , and its ultimate desired path by politicians to negotiate a Comprehensive Plan of Action ( CPOA ) are preeminent issues in the global press and political circles .
1047: The JPOA is a temporary agreement made between Iran and an intergovernmental negotiating body consisting of China , France , the Russian Federation , the Un ited Kingdom , the United States and Germany .
1048: The agreement was originally intended to be a six - month period in which the Iranian government would reduce its stockpile of enriched uranium fuel and suspend specific aspects of its nuclear energy programs in exchange for the UN Security Council relaxing of specific sanctions previously imposed against Iran .
1049: During this time of suspended nuclear research activities and Looking Forward eased sanctions , negotiating parties would discuss the details of a more permanent agreement , known as the Comprehensive Plan of Action ( CPOA ) .
1050: The JPOA could be a driver or tipping point for future cyber attacks by Iran against western targets .
1051: Iran has publicly noted the understanding that negotiations can be influenced and has demonstrated historically that it is willing ( and has capabilities ) to conduct cyber operations to influence negotiations if it sees fit to do so .
1052: It has been publicly speculated that Iran has conducted retaliatory attacks , notably the Shamoon incident in 2012 .
1053: Recent open - source activities in the Iranian underground suggest Iran may be attempting to structure or resource for possible future cyber operations .
1054: There have been visibility changes with regard to information surrounding Iranian hackers , as well as forums and websites .
1055: Popular forums for Iranian hackers ISCN and Shabgard have been shut down and are no longer publicly accessible .
1056: Despite the shutdowns , there will likely be little change to the communication occurring between affiliated hackers in closed communications pathways .
1057: The closing of these forums could be in anticipation of future malicious activity and a desire to decrease the public profile of individuals in the Iranian underground .
1058: There are also clear links between the Iranian government hacking contests intended to identify hackers with advanced skills and to learn advanced methods of network intrusion .
1059: For example , in November 2013 , just before the JPOA agreement was signed , Sharif University of Technology conducted a contest for " innovative methods " of computer network intrusions and defense against such intrusions .
1060: Based on the contest announcements , Iranian government cyber security authorities had access to the students ' submissions in the contest , and those submissions were not released to the public but rather kept private to only those with access to the contest submissions .
1061: Looking Forward Iranian adversaries such as ROCKET KITTEN , FLYING KITTEN , and CHARMING KITTEN were quite active during 2014 targeting western governments and companies .
1062: The motivation to attack such targets will only increase during 2015 .
1063: However , should the process around the JPOA and CPOA take a turn that Iran perceives as disadvantageous , the motivation will likely greatly increase .
1064: Recent revelations indicate that ROCKET KITTEN may have , in fact , targeted the JPOA negotiations using spear phishing that may have targeted diplomats involved in the meetings .
1065: Cyber Spillover from Regional Conflicts Last year 's report included cyber spillover as something to look for in 2014 , and it will be equally as important in 2015 .
1066: Increasingly , real- world physical conflicts are carrying with them associated cyber components .
1067: Sometimes the related cyber operations are carried out by entities directly engaged in the conflict , and other times entities not directly involved will engage in cyber operations in an attempt to support one side or the other .
1068: It is not possible to predict all possible conflicts in 2015 , but there are three primary areas to keep an eye on .
1069: The conflict that may see the most significant uptick in associated activity is the one centered around ISIS .
1070: The Syrian civil war saw quite a bit of associated cyber operations against western targets in 2013 , many of which were attributed to the DEADEYE JACKAL adversary ( Syrian Electronic Army ) .
1071: Since that time , the ISIS terrorist group has become a significant threat in the region and appears to be capable of bringing resources to bear to carry out malicious cyber attacks .
1072: Already , in early January 2015 , a group calling itself CyberCaliphate and declaring support for ISIS hacked the social media presence of U.S.
1073: Central Command and used it to spread Islamist propaganda .
1074: It is likely that this and other related groups supporting the Islamist cause will engage in operations that support ISIS objectives .
1075: Most of this activity is likely to be a nuisance , such as defacements and Looking Forward low - level DDOS attacks , but it is possible that more advanced actors could carry out targeted or even destructive attacks .
1076: The South China Sea will be an area to continue to watch in 2015 .
1077: As discussed above , tensions in this area drove a great deal of targeted intrusion activity from China - based adversaries in 2014 .
1078: Tensions subsided toward the end of 2014 , but the region is rich in natural resources and countries there , particularly China , are eager to lay claim to those resources .
1079: Because of this , there is a significant possibility that the conflict will flare up again in the coming year .
1080: One thing that could temper the possibility for conflict is if oil prices remain low , making oil exploration in the area potentially less lucrative .
1081: Ukraine is the third region to keep an eye on for possible cyber spillover in 2015 .
1082: The physical conflict there already spilled over into cyberspace , as was discussed above .
1083: So long as the Ukrainian conflict remains unresolved and foreign governments continue to exert pressure on Russia via economic sanctions , expect continued Russian targeting of governments , particularly those in Europe and the U.S.
1084: Another related contributing factor to Russian cyber operations is the falling price of oil .
1085: Russia 's economy is deeply dependent on oil prices .
1086: The precipitous fall in the price of oil at the end of 2014 and going into 2015 has already caused a great deal of economic turmoil in Russia .
1087: An extended period of low oil prices could result in increased malicious cyber activity from Russian adversaries against foreign governments and private sector organizations .
1088: The Future for PoS Attacks PoS malware experienced a great deal of success during 2014 , however upcoming changes may force changes in payment- processing systems in the U.S.
1089: For example , several major credit card companies are expected to institute new policies in October 2015 that will shift liability for fraudulent transactions to whomever Looking Forward is using the weakest payment - processing systems .
1090: The purpose of this is to drive retailers to adopt EMV ( Europay , MasterCard , and Visa ) standards , which entail chip and PIN cards that use a combination of the traditional PIN number and an embedded microchip that encrypts vital information .
1091: This type of card offers a more secure payment card solution for consumers .
1092: Additionally , several alternative solutions , such as Apple Pay and Google Wallet , have started becoming adopted , allowing for payment via token systems .
1093: In theses systems , rather than a card number being transmitted , a one - time token is passed from a consumer 's device to the retailer .
1094: The advantage to this system is that in the event of the token being obtained by an unauthorized party , it can not be reused for later transactions .
1095: Adoption of these newer payment processes should provide consumers with more secure payment methods and make it more difficult for criminals seeking to make money off these systems .
1096: There will be some lag time in 2015 as retailers and banks move to put these improvements in place , during which cybercriminals will still be able to exploit the current , antiquated payment processing systems in the U.S.
1097: However , the newer processes , once in place , should lead to a decline in the type of PoS attacks seen over the past year .
1098: Despite this decline , it is almost certain that the implementation of more secure methods will lead cybercriminals to develop more sophisticated means by which to attack payment- processing systems .
1099: Destructive and Disruptive Attacks Destructive attacks ( such as those carried out by SILENT CHOLLIMA ) and disruptive attacks ( such as the DDOS activity against gaming platforms ) garnered headlines at the end of 2014 .
1100: The high - profile nature of these attacks does not necessarily indicate that they will grow in popularity in 2015 , however it is Looking Forward possible that the success of these attacks may encourage other groups to engage in destructive or disruptive operations to advance their interests .
1101: As an example of this , a series of disruptive attacks in December targeted online gaming platforms .
1102: These attacks manifested in the form of DDOS operations carried out by the LizardSquad group briefly discussed above .
1103: The attacks came in two waves , the first of which was in early December when the Xbox Live and PlayStation networks were knocked offline for a short period of time .
1104: The second wave of attacks occurred on 25 December 2014 when the Xbox and PlayStation online platforms suffered more outages that LizardSquad claimed responsibility for .
1105: CrowdStrike Intelligence is also aware of DDOS threats against other gaming platforms including Valve Software , which appeared to be targeted by a DNS amplification DDOS attack that is similar to previous LizardSquad activity .
1106: Malicious actors have already engaged in disruptive campaigns in early 2015 .
1107: Following the January terrorist attacks in France , a group of Islamist hackers known as Fallaga conducted DDOS attacks against servers hosting websites for French foreign embassies .
1108: Soon after , another Islamist group identifying with ISIS took control of the Twitter and YouTube accounts for U.S.
1109: Central Command and posted a number of messages threatening U.S.
1111: Organizations in all sectors should be aware of , and prepared for , destructive and disruptive attacks .
1112: These operations are often motivated by a specific grievance , but sometimes no clear motivation can be established .
1113: Continuous monitoring for publicized threats against an organization , or for potential areas of controversy that could motivate malicious activity , is vital to detect and prepare for these types of attacks .
1114: The question now is : How do you incorporate intelligence into your daily defenses and prioritize resources based on risk to your business ? Conclusion In the course of reviewing 2014 , there were so many interesting events , adversaries , and innovations that selecting examples for this report was an incredible challenge .
1115: The CrowdStrike Intelligence team spent much time narrowing the scope of topics covered herein .
1116: The adversaries in 2014 proved , if nothing else , to be dynamic , persistent , and innovative .
